awd_titl_txt: Philadelphia Regional Noyce Partnership Scholarship Program
awd_abstract_narration:
The Philadelphia Regional Noyce Scholarship Program is a Noyce Track 1 Scholarships and Stipends project at Saint Joseph's University. The project will address the national need for preparing highly effective secondary mathematics and science teachers for successful teaching careers in high-need urban environments.  Six colleges and universities in the Philadelphia region will collaborate to increase: (i) the number of STEM majors that become teachers in high-need schools in the Philadelphia region and who persist as teachers; (ii) Noyce scholars' understanding of Culturally Responsive Teaching practices; and (iii) Noyce scholars' knowledge of Education for Sustainability content and pedagogical practices. The project will produce new STEM teachers drawn from biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics majors and post-baccalaureates at the partnering institutions.  Noyce scholars will participate in three years of learning community work, starting in their final year of pre-service preparation and continuing for their first two years of teaching. Through the scholars' participation in these learning communities, they will learn how to build social networks that will positively support acclimation to the teaching profession. Scholars will use teaching and learning strategies based on education for sustainability core standards. Additionally, twenty-four students from a local community college will take part in a summer internship program with the goal of increasing their interest in pursuing careers in STEM teaching at one of the partnering institutions.  

The project will award one-year Noyce scholarships to 55 undergraduate STEM majors and STEM post-baccalaureates. The scholarship granting institutions in the partnership are Arcadia University, Bryn Mawr College, La Salle University, Saint Joseph's University, and Temple University. They are joined in the project by two additional partnerships: the Community College of Philadelphia and the School District of Philadelphia. By bringing scholars from multiple institutions together, the project will create a regional community of practice that can engage a critical mass of participants, contribute to the formation of a robust professional social network, and foster culturally relevant and sustainability education practices. The project will investigate the degree to which these supports help retain new STEM teachers in the profession, resulting in addressing the critical need to attract well-prepared STEM teachers to the Philadelphia region.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2018 the Philadelphia Regional Noyce Partnership (PRNP) received a Track1 Noyce Scholarship award from the National Science Foundation to recruit and develop 55 new STEM Teachers from 5 institutions of higher education and to encourage 25 students attending Philadelphia Community College to think about being a STEM teacher.  One year after recruiting the first cohort of new STEM teachers and interns, COVID put up roadblocks in the way of succeeding in our goal.  Nevertheless, PRNP not only succeeded in its goal, but also found innovative ways to do it.  Our journey to success includes intellectual merit and broader impacts as well as a profound impact on the lives of the 95 program participants (72 Scholars and 23 Interns) and the students they are teaching.

 

The five IHE partners, Arcadia University, Bryn Mawr College, La Salle University, St Joseph’s University and Temple University worked together to define a recruitment strategy and selection process, a curriculum framework and staff for a New Teacher Support Program and an innovative way to bring additional STEM teachers into the program as a fee for service offering to West Chester University. They worked together with Temple University and Community College of Philadelphia (CCP) to establish a for credit STEM pedagogy course and field experience that CCP students could take that would be transferable to the Temple UTeach Program.  From its inception, the NSF capacity-building grant that funded the development of PRNP, now known as Philadelphia Regional Institute for STEM Educators (PRISE), has had collaboration as its hallmark and has been “doing together what we cannot do alone” for the past 15 years.  Part of the intellectual merit of the PRNP-Scholarship program stems from the innovative concept of working together for collective impact.  Working together in theory is not new or innovative, but in practice it rarely happens in academia.  The networking done by the PRNP-S partners among IHEs was contextualized through collaborations among faculty, administrators and other personnel, including various departments and offices. We developed a sense of integral community that had similar visions, missions and policies.  

 

Moreover, this collective impact brought to secondary education 72 new STEM teachers, all steeped in the understanding that their purpose is not only to teach a STEM discipline, but also to teach their students how to realize that knowledge in their lives for the good of their community, be it their classroom, their school or their neighborhoods.  With an equity lens, participants in the PRNP-S New Teacher Support program, learned the importance of giving their students voice, helping them appreciate the multiple perspectives and lived experiences of their peers and how building a classroom of cooperation, not compliance, leads to an engagement in the subject they are teaching that is meaningful and useful.  For STEM Education, this is truly a transformative approach, bringing new life to a discipline that has been stuck in a system that has not provided equitable learning experiences for all students.

 

The broader impacts of the Philadelphia Regional Noyce Partnership-Scholarship program includes a researched based, three year, monthly professional learning community and a support network of STEM teachers and university faculty. These programmatic components provide resources and support for the development and retention of not only the teachers who have gone through the program, but also of their colleagues in the many schools where they teach in the Philadelphia area and in places as far reaching in this new Zoom age as Wyoming.  This combination of a professional learning community and a support network has ensured that 90% of the teachers who have gone through the PRNP-S New Teacher Support Program are being retained and sustained in the profession since the first group of recruits started teaching 5 years ago.  When this happens, it means better outcomes for the thousands of students the PRNP-S teachers are educating, because consistency and an asset-based mindset matter to academic success.

 

In addition  to the PRNP-Scholarship intellectual merits and broader impacts in the areas of inclusion, STEM education, infrastructure, and partnerships as described above, society benefits from citizens that are developed in the classrooms of teachers who care about who their students are and believe that all their students can be successful in STEM.  Helping students understand that they BELONG in the STEM community encourages, prepares and drives students towards STEM careers.  In this ever-increasing technological world that needs workers skilled in STEM disciplines and in the understanding that the work they will do in STEM fields must be sustainable, excellent STEM teachers are critical to building the workforce in our society. PRNP-S teachers take seriously the foundation of the secondary students that they are sending on to colleges and the trades and as a society we should take more seriously the value of STEM educators for the well-being of society.         

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2024
Modified by: Tetyana Berezovski
